newsitem.title: SWEDEN: FORECAST - Swedish CPI seen up 0.1 pct in May.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - Swedish CPI seen up 0.1 pct in May.

text.p: The Swedish consumer price index (CPI) is expected to rise 0.1 percent in May for year-on-year inflation of 0.4 percent, a Reuter poll of 13 analysts showed on Friday.
Forecasts ranged from zero to a rise of 0.3 percent in the month, corresponding to a year-on-year rate of between 0.2 percent and 0.5 percent.
For the full year 1997, eleven of the analysts envisaged an average inflation of 0.9 percent with forecasts ranging from 0.6 percent to one percent.
The central bank, the Riksbank, forecast in its latest quarterly inflation report a day earlier that the annual rate of inflation would be about one percent in 1997 and two percent in 1998.
It saw the underlying rate of inflation in 1997 and 1998 at 1.5 to two percent.
The Riksbank targets inflation of two percent with an allowed deviation of one percentage point on either side.
In April, consumer prices rose 0.5 percent for a year-on-year rise of 0.2 percent. In May last year, CPI fell 0.1 percent for a year-on-year rise of 1.0 percent.
Statistics Sweden has changed its CPI figure to include costs for renewing mortgages to get more favourable interest rates. This pushes the rate of inflation somewhat higher.
The statistics agency will release May CPI data at 0715 GMT on June 12.

Analysts interviewed for the poll came from: Aragon, Carnegie, Consensus, Den Danske Bank, Hagstromer & Qviberg, Handelsbanken, HSBC Midland, JP Morgan, Lehman Brothers, Penser, S-E-Banken, Transferator, UBS, Unibank and Ohman.
